bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 162, Number 109 (Thursday, July 7, 2016)]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. LANCE:H.R. 5674.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, Sec. 8, Clause 1, of the United StateConstitution This states that ``Congress shall have the powerto. . .lay and collect taxes, duties, imposts and excises, topay the debts and provide for the common defense and generalwelfare of the United States.''[Page H4549]

item.title: Guardians of America's Freedom Medal Act

latestAction.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on Armed Services.

item.title: Guardians of America's Freedom Medal Act

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Military Personnel.

item.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Military Personnel.
Referred to the House Committee on Armed Services.

summary.text:
Guardians of America's Freedom Medal Act

This bill requires each military department to carry out a program to award medals or other commendations to military working dogs and their handlers to recognize valor or meritorious achievement.

bill.title: Guardians of America's Freedom Medal Act

item.title: Guardians of America's Freedom Medal Act
To provide for the award of medals or other commendations to handlers of military working dogs and military working dogs, and for other purposes.
Guardians of America's Freedom Medal Act

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Military Personnel.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
